headline: Danish Doctors’ Group Wants to End Circumcision for Boys
abstract: The medical association in Denmark said the procedure should be an “informed personal choice” that men make for themselves when they reach adulthood.
lead_paragraph: A major doctors association in Denmark has recommended ending circumcisions for boys, saying the procedure should be “an informed personal choice” that young men make for themselves when they reach adulthood.

headline: Former Insys Officials Charged in Scheme to Push Its Painkiller
abstract: According to the indictment, the employees, including the C.E.O., offered bribes to doctors to get them to prescribe more of the company’s product, Subsys.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors brought racketeering charges on Thursday against several former executives of Insys Therapeutics, a small Arizona drug company, saying they were part of a scheme that involved aggressive sales of the powerful and highly addictive pain drug fentanyl.

headline: The Tao of Matthew McConaughey
abstract: You thought he was a movie star. But he has been a guru all along.
lead_paragraph: Matthew McConaughey has two movies out this month. In one, he gives voice to an animated koala who organizes a singing contest. In the other, he plays a schlubby dreamer turned jungle adventurer.

headline: Sisters’ Deaths Reveal Strains in City’s Efforts to Tackle Homelessness
abstract: The tragedy underscored the challenges Mayor Bill de Blasio faces in addressing an issue where even the potential solutions can create further problems.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York took responsibility for the city’s worsening homelessness problem, saying, “I own it.” Less than two hours later, his pledge took on tragic implications, when two young sisters were burned to death in the South Bronx by radiator steam in city-financed housing for the homeless.

headline: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 14
abstract: Quarterback Carson Palmer and running back Jeremy Hill are good starts, as is the Jets’ Matt Forte, if you’re feeling brave.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: Georgia Fugitive, Who Settled Quietly in Connecticut, Dies at 71
abstract: Robert Stackowitz, who fled a Georgia prison nearly 50 years ago, was discovered earlier this year living under an alias in Sherman, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A Connecticut man who fled from a Georgia prison nearly 50 years ago and then settled into an unassuming life in his home state died on Monday, after a monthslong campaign to remain free.

headline: Donald Trump’s E.P.A. Nominee: Putting Planet’s Future at Risk
abstract: “What does Mr. Trump do? He meets with Al Gore for a photo op, then appoints a climate change denier to head the E.P.A.,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Ella Fontanals-Cisneros’s Collection, Latin American Roots Run Deep
abstract: Geometric abstraction from Latin America figures prominently in Ms. Fontanals-Cisneros’s collection of some 3,300 works.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Art fans often talk about collecting in terms of first love. The Cuban-born Ella Fontanals-Cisneros says she fell hard in the 1980s for a work in Jesús Rafael Soto’s “Vibration” series, featuring panels painted with black-and-white parallel lines juxtaposed with wood and wire.

headline: Government Shutdown Looms Over Stopgap Spending Measure
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Mines and Mining', 'Coal', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The House voted to fund the government through April 28, but Senate Democrats object to a provision on extending health benefits for retired coal miners.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to finance the government through late April, but a snag over the measure in the Senate threatens a shutdown of operations this weekend.

headline: John Glenn: A Patriot in Space and Politics
abstract: A look at the life of Mr. Glenn, the first American to orbit the Earth and a 24-year senator from Ohio.
lead_paragraph: A look at the life of Mr. Glenn, the first American to orbit the Earth and a 24-year senator from Ohio.

headline: John Glenn, American Hero of the Space Age, Dies at 95
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Pilots', 'Cold War Era', 'Exploration and Explorers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Mr. Glenn was a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, then became a national political figure representing Ohio in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: John Glenn, a freckle-faced son of Ohio who was hailed as a national hero and a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, then became a national political figure for 24 years in the Senate, died on Thursday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 95.

headline: Review: You Quit? Think Again, ‘Sword Master’
abstract: A swordsman has grown tired of his work and his love in this remake of “Death Duel,” a nod to the Chinese magic-and-martial arts genre wuxia.
lead_paragraph: Stuffed with demon warriors, vamping concubines and overblown acrobatics, Derek Yee’s “Sword Master” packs a lot into its 105 minutes. A remake of Chor Yuen’s “Death Duel” (1977), this nostalgic nod to the Chinese magic-and-martial arts genre known as wuxia mixes love story and clan war with equal amounts of silliness and heart.

headline: Review: ‘Slash’ Has Proud Outcasts With Bold Imaginations
abstract: This sweet-natured coming-of-age movie is perhaps more complicated than most by having characters whose sexual orientations are in flux.
lead_paragraph: “Slash” opens with a science-fiction sequence that would fit comfortably into “Dune.” It’s quickly revealed to have sprung from the mind of Neil (Michael Johnston), a 15-year-old who writes erotic fan fiction. The twist is that the muscular hero and villain abruptly cease fighting and begin making out. Neil, who is questioning his sexuality, is teased at school, particularly after his composition book is passed around a classroom.

headline: Yankees’ Three-Year Plan: Keep Building, Then Collect
abstract: By 2019, the last one that ties closer Aroldis Chapman to the team, the Yankees envision a competitive roster of matured prospects and star acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md. — You might think a $17.2 million annual salary, a new benchmark for closers, would be enough to get a five-year commitment to the Yankees from Aroldis Chapman. But that is not how free agency works.

headline: The Economics of Regional Self-Esteem
abstract: Everything is an insult, apparently.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump won the electoral college at least in part by promising to bring coal jobs back to Appalachia and manufacturing jobs back to the Rust Belt. Neither promise can be honored – for the most part we’re talking about jobs lost, not to unfair foreign competition, but to technological change. But a funny thing happens when people like me try to point that out: we get enraged responses from economists who feel an affinity for the working people of the afflicted regions – responses that assume that trying to do the numbers must reflect contempt for regional cultures, or something.

headline: Dismantling Climate Rules Isn’t So Easy
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Trump supporters hope to wipe away Obama-era environmental regulations. But that may prove difficult to do.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has named Scott Pruitt, a leading opponent of President Obama’s signature environmental initiatives, as his nominee to head the Environmental Protection Agency. Mr. Pruitt, Oklahoma’s attorney general, is closely linked to fossil fuel industries and is a climate change skeptic. He was most likely chosen to reverse these environmental initiatives, a deeply disturbing turn in the nation’s effort to slow climate change.

headline: Life Expectancy in U.S. Declines Slightly, and Researchers Are Puzzled
abstract: It dropped for the first time since 1993, to 78.8 years.
lead_paragraph: American life expectancy is in decline for the first time since 1993, when H.I.V.-related deaths were at their peak. But this time, researchers can’t identify a single problem driving the drop, and are instead pointing to a number of factors, from heart disease to suicides, that have caused a greater number of deaths.

headline: Review: The Team That Put Israeli Basketball ‘On the Map’
abstract: Dani Menkin’s documentary recounts this team’s unlikely run to the European Cup championship in 1977, a year in Israel’s history that was more fraught than usual.
lead_paragraph: How much do you know about the European basketball league? How much do you want to know about the European basketball league? Come on, don’t be provincial. How about the Israeli team in the European basketball league?

headline: Reporting the Moon Landing
abstract: John Noble Wilford tells how, as a New York Times science reporter in July 1969, he wrote the front page article “Men Walk on Moon.” It is the first interview in a new Times series, “I Was There.”
lead_paragraph: John Noble Wilford tells how, as a New York Times science reporter in July 1969, he wrote the front page article “Men Walk on Moon.” It is the first interview in a new Times series, “I Was There.”

headline: Reporting the Moon Landing
abstract: The New York Times begins a new series with a video featuring John Noble Wilford, the Times science reporter who covered the moon landing.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

headline: Review: You’ve Got to Fight for Your Right to an ‘Office Christmas Party’
abstract: Directed by Josh Gordon and Will Speck, this bawdy comedy is full of familiar faces, including Kate McKinnon and Courtney B. Vance, behaving badly.
lead_paragraph: Nothing says Christmas like decadence, debauchery and mayhem, at least when comic actors like T. J. Miller, Kate McKinnon and Rob Corddry are involved. But how did the normally dignified Courtney B. Vance fall in with this crowd?

headline: A New Yorker’s Guide to the Silvery Sounds of the Season
abstract: Listings of holiday music and special events throughout the month of December.
lead_paragraph: A guide to holiday music and special events. See our classical music listings here.

headline: Review: ‘Harry Benson: Shoot First,’ on Photographing the Beatles and Others
abstract: This adulatory profile focuses on a photojournalist who has documented many high-profile figures, but it skips some hard questions.
lead_paragraph: “Harry Benson: Shoot First” is an engaging but too worshipful documentary about Mr. Benson, a photographer who has been taking noteworthy pictures since the early days of the Beatles. The film, by Justin Bare and Matthew Miele, would be better if it spent less time gushing about how great Mr. Benson is and more time confronting some of the questions his approach raises.

headline: Six Minimal — and Inexpensive — All-Black Watches
abstract: At under $200 each, these sleek, elegant timepieces make perfect gifts.
lead_paragraph: At under $200 each, these sleek, elegant timepieces make perfect gifts.

headline: Review: An Afghan in a Strange Land (California) in ‘Burn Country’
abstract: A former assistant to a war journalist resettles in small-town America, where culture clashes turn mysterious and dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Dominic Rains is quietly captivating in “Burn Country,” an amorphous study in table-turning directed by Ian Olds, a documentarian who is trying his first feature.

headline: Boris Johnson Lashes Out at Saudi Arabia and Gets Stung at Home
abstract: He had accused the country, a British ally, of “puppeteering” in “proxy wars” across the Middle East and of “abusing Islam,” and he received an upbraiding from Prime Minister Theresa May.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Boris Johnson, Britain’s famously undiplomatic chief diplomat, finally seems to have gone too far.

headline: Review: A Trip to Hell, via the VCR, in ‘Beyond the Gates’
abstract: In this horror movie, two brothers play an old-school board game with a videotape and run into Barbara Crampton of “Re-Animator.”
lead_paragraph: All hail the VCR: the more or less obsolete technology that keeps on giving. Videotapes and the machines that play them are frequent props in the current crush of nostalgia for the 1980s and ’90s. The latest example is the horror movie “Beyond the Gates,” which shows early promise but eventually ends up in the bin of ordinariness.

headline: ISIS Remains Threat in Libya Despite Defeat in Surt, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Officials say surviving fighters could go underground and exploit the economic and political vacuum, threatening not only the country but also its neighbors and possibly Europe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State, though driven from its coastal stronghold in Surt this week, still has several hundred fighters who have dispersed across Libya and pose a threat to the country, its neighbors and, potentially, Europe, according to American officials and the Pentagon’s Africa Command.

headline: Review: Angels, Some of This Earth, in ‘Lost and Beautiful’
abstract: A palace and a water buffalo calf figure in this Pietro Marcello film — part fable, part documentary — set in the Campania region of Italy.
lead_paragraph: Part documentary, part beast fable, Pietro Marcello’s “Lost and Beautiful” is a loving act of cultural preservation. It also pays tribute to another such act: the brave and selfless efforts of Tommaso, a shepherd in the southern Italian region of Campania, to protect an 18th-century Bourbon palace from falling into ruin.

headline: Review: ‘Can I Get a Witness?’ Takes James Baldwin’s Message to Church
abstract: In Meshell Ndegeocello’s show at Harlem Stage, “The Fire Next Time” might as well be the Bible. And the big question is, “How are you surviving 2016?”
lead_paragraph: A fierce tide of feeling — rage and despair, love and hope and exaltation — courses through “Can I Get a Witness?,” an almost indefinable work of music theater created by the performer and musician Meshell Ndegeocello, and inspired by “The Fire Next Time,” James Baldwin’s incisive polemic about race in America, first published in 1963.

headline: Review: Juilliard Students Try Out a Searing New Dance
abstract: In this year’s edition of “New Dances” at the school, Pam Tanowitz’s “thunder rolling along afterward” exhilarated the junior class.
lead_paragraph: The first-year students in Juilliard’s dance division already have much of what it takes, on a technical level, to become professional dancers. To be accepted into the program, a dancer has to show immense promise. But to watch the school’s annual “New Dances” concert, featuring new works by four choreographers — one piece per class — is to see how four years of training can build confidence and nuance on top of great technique.

headline: Review: ‘Frank & Lola,’ Retreading Old Ground
abstract: Frankie and Johnny’s story returns, written and directed by Matthew Ross, but not much has changed except the actors and how well they fit together.
lead_paragraph: Its title is an early tip-off that “Frank & Lola” will be a new riff on Frankie and Johnny’s old troubles. Immortalized in song and onstage, these two have lent their names and heartache to a couple of films. (The movie shares its title with a Jimmy Buffett song.) They’re back in shadow form in “Frank & Lola,” this time with an unpersuasively paired Michael Shannon and Imogen Poots as Las Vegas souls who, after tumbling into bed, fall for each other. Soon, Frank and Lola learn that love still hurts, especially when tendrils of jealously start twisting through the story and he confuses abandon with possession.

headline: Conquering River, Jungle and the World’s Toughest Bike Race
abstract: La Ruta de Los Conquistadores, a three-day race across Costa Rica, pits participants against steep climbs, muddy trails and waterways that may or may not contain crocodiles.
lead_paragraph: MATINA, Costa Rica — Just keep moving. Even if only an inch forward. That’s the key.

headline: Review: A ‘Rudolph’ for Inclusion (at Least if You’re a Guy)
abstract: “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Musical,” at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, has bucks as well as does, but its message of equality is not fully realized.
lead_paragraph: According to “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Musical,” there’s something even more unheard-of than letting a funny-looking buck play in any reindeer games: allowing a doe to join in.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Four Ai Weiwei shows; Rob Pruitt’s Obama portraits; Michele Abeles exploring where sculpture begins; and Paul Pfeiffer deconstructs professional boxing.
lead_paragraph: Four shows running through Dec. 23 at Mary Boone Gallery, 745 Fifth Avenue, and Mary Boone Gallery, 541 West 24th Street, Chelsea; Lisson Gallery, 504 West 24th Street, Chelsea; and Jeffrey Deitch, 18 Wooster Street, SoHo; maryboonegallery.com; lissongallery.com; deitch.com.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers react to a recent essay by Calvin Trillin and more.
lead_paragraph: Worse and Worse

headline: Review: Beat a New Path Down a Familiar Yellow Brick Road in ‘Elements of Oz’
abstract: This loose, loopy and enjoyable seminar on the making of “The Wizard of Oz” combines live video and performance.
lead_paragraph: A loose, loopy and enjoyable seminar on the making of “The Wizard of Oz” and its influence on pop culture, this Builders Association production, running through Dec. 18, combines live video and performance. Several famous scenes from the movie are more or less filmed anew before us; the digital video is dazzlingly pristine, and it’s fun to watch the wry comic impersonations of the original performances.. [Read the original review] 800-838-3006, 3ldnyc.org

headline: The Perils of Order, Taken to the Extreme
abstract: The German artist Hanne Darboven’s magnum opus offers a personal, imperfect vision that absorbs, but never fully clarifies, the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: What force drives societal disaster: too little order, or too much of it? These days of presidential interregnum have seen newspapers’ opinion pages fill with warnings of tyranny and autocracy, fueled by the election of a man whose campaign rhetoric showed disregard for normal rules of conduct. Yet, for many philosophers of the postwar era, too much order seemed just as dangerous as too little. You may dream of perfectly rational government, but fitting the complexities of life into dispassionate systems poses its own hazards. Taken to extremes, as Theodor W. Adorno insisted, the Enlightenment principles of reason and logic would pave the road to Auschwitz.

headline: Review: God Is Alive and Crabby, According to ‘The Brand New Testament’
abstract: Jaco Van Dormael’s satire follows a bored deity who, from his apartment in Brussels, plays jokes on humans.
lead_paragraph: In the Belgian filmmaker Jaco Van Dormael’s wickedly amusing religious satire, “The Brand New Testament,” God (Benoît Poelvoorde) is a snarling, meanspirited bully who rules the universe from an apartment in Brussels. Inside his locked office, surrounded by walls of card files, the tyrannical, perpetually bored deity sits behind a computer and plays nasty practical jokes on humans. A favorite pastime is contriving Laws of Annoyance, like making sure that when a piece of toast falls, it always lands with the jelly side down.

headline: Review: Katie Holmes Directs Her First Feature, ‘All We Had’
abstract: A teenage girl and her downtrodden mother struggle to build a normal life, but any progress they make seems to unravel.
lead_paragraph: Homelessness, alcoholism, real estate chicanery, the financial crisis, teenage drug abuse and transgender discrimination: These are some of the themes dutifully trotted out and glossed over in the screen adaptation of Annie Weatherwax’s 2014 novel, “All We Had.” Although sensitively handled in the film, it all adds up to an overload of baggage for a well-meaning but formulaic movie with not enough time to transcend predictable clichés.

headline: The Russian Avant-Garde Rising in ‘A Revolutionary Impulse’
abstract: This is MoMA’s first show that traces the progress of one art movement, assembled entirely from the museum’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art more or less set the standard for the broad swath of media typically collected by a fine-art museum by creating the first departments of photography, film, architecture and design. But then a weird primness set in: Departmental holdings were rarely allowed to mix in the galleries. The divisions remained intact even as the hybrid forms of 1970s art sowed confusion. (Performance art, video, Conceptual Art, anyone?) Then, to the dismay of many, the system was once more reinforced by the museum’s 2004 redesign, which gave all departments their own dedicated galleries.

headline: Review: In ‘The Private Life of Mrs. Sharma,’ a Search for Release
abstract: A woman in Delhi whose brain has been annexed by worry craves an escape.
lead_paragraph: The brain is capable of remarkable flimflam. We act on impulse, and only later start looking for a logical justification for it; we somehow find ways to intellectually defend what’s in our gut. As the psychologist Jonathan Haidt likes to say, we rely on an inner lawyer, not an inner scientist, to do our moral reasoning.

headline: The Freaky Food Chain Behind Your Lobster Dinner
abstract: If you trace most food chains back far enough, you get sunlight. But trace back that of the Caribbean spiny lobster, and you get swamp gas.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever ordered a lobster tail from Red Lobster, there’s a good chance some of your meal can be traced back to swamp gas.

headline: Follow-Up: A New Ending in Tale of Young Woman From Rural India
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The reporter Ellen Barry follows up on a young woman who was the subject of her report about efforts in India to place poor young rural women in urban manufacturing jobs.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider provides behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, The Times’s South Asia Bureau Chief, Ellen Barry, follows up on a report she wrote earlier this fall about efforts in India to place poor young rural women in minimum-wage manufacturing jobs.

abstract: The collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art holds a number of remarkable depictions of powerful women. Here’s our 50-minute critic’s guide.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers live booked-up lives, and tourists are the busiest people in town. Who else dashes in beat-the-clock time from the World Trade Center to Rockefeller Center, to Trump Tower to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, pausing for selfies at each stop?

lead_paragraph: Galas for the Committee to Protect Journalists, Berggruen Institute, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and the Food Allergy Research and Education group.

headline: Thinkers and Scientists
abstract: Galas were held for the Committee to Protect Journalists, Berggruen Institute, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, and Food Allergy Research and Education.
lead_paragraph: The 19th annual Food Allergy Ball, which benefits Food Allergy Research and Education, was Dec. 5 at the Waldorf Astoria. The Berggruen Institute, a philosophical think tank based in Los Angeles, awarded the inaugural Berggruen Prize on Dec. 1 to the Canadian philosopher Charles Taylor at the New York Public Library; the $1 million award recognizes a living thinker of great influence. The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory honored Alan Alda and P. Roy Vaglos at its Double Helix Medals ceremony Dec. 1 at the American Museum of Natural History. And the Committee to Protect Journalists held its International Press Freedom Awards on Nov. 22 at the Waldorf Astoria.

headline: Kathleen Collins’s Short Stories Were Almost Lost to History
abstract: In a traveling trunk, a daughter discovered her mother’s lost literary legacy. Now, nearly 30 years after Ms. Collins’s death, a collection has been published.
lead_paragraph: When Nina Collins was 19 and studying in Europe, she had a distressing phone conversation with her mother. I have cancer, and you need to come home, her mother said, but don’t worry, I’m going to be fine.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The holidays are upon us, and it’s time to think about books for the giving and books we’d love to receive ourselves. Our list this week is heavy — but lighthearted too! — on books about the visual and performance arts. Among them are works that put us in a celebratory mood, or at least get our minds off more mundane and/or troubling matters.

headline: Governors Compromise on Port Authority Plan. Commissioners Don’t Go Along.
abstract: They refused to vote on a draft of a 10-year plan for spending on major projects like a replacement for the bus terminal in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey traditionally serves just two masters: the governors of the two states. But as they showed again on Thursday, the agency’s fractious commissioners do not seem to understand that.

headline: The Last Word: John Glenn
abstract: John Glenn, a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, sat down with John Schwartz in 2012 — the 50th anniversary of his flight — to talk about making history and that “beautiful view.”
lead_paragraph: John Glenn, a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, sat down with John Schwartz in 2012 — the 50th anniversary of his flight — to talk about making history and that “beautiful view.”

headline: With Trump, Fear the Social Service Cuts, Not the Traffic
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Affordable Housing', 'Group Homes and Supportive Housing']
abstract: Congestion in Midtown will seem like a board-game problem if fears about drastic federal cuts are borne out, at a time when New York faces a growing homelessness crisis.
lead_paragraph: For the last several weeks, discussions of the ways a Trump presidency will affect life in New York City have revolved largely around questions of inconvenience, when they might have been better cast as questions of sustainability. Congestion in Midtown will seem like a board-game problem if fears about drastic federal cuts to social services are borne out, at a time when New York, like other major cities, faces a growing homelessness crisis. Conveniently, Donald J. Trump’s naming of Ben Carson as his choice to run the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development provides us with a vehicle in which we might drive closer to some of the more darkly imagined consequences.

headline: What Happened to Walloon Park?
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: A reader asks about a park-within-a-park near the Korean War Memorial in Battery Park.
lead_paragraph: Q. Before Hurricane Sandy, a lovely, messy little circular park-within-a-park near the Korean War Memorial in Battery Park had a sign that labeled it Walloon Park. That area reopened just last year and is now labeled Jerusalem Cove. It features a vegetable and flower garden as well as the cedars and the circular labyrinth that were there before (though the cedars are half-dead, poor things, from hurricane damage). What happened to the name Walloon Park?

headline: U.N. Says Nearly One in Four Children Live in Conflict or Disaster Zones
keywords: ['War and Revolution', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: About 535 million children worldwide now live in countries destabilized by conflicts and calamities, Unicef announced.
lead_paragraph: More than a half-billion children, or roughly one in four, now live in countries affected by conflicts or other disasters, the United Nations Children’s Fund said Thursday.

headline: Canada Wonders, if U.S. Balks, Is Carbon Pricing Still the Answer?
keywords: ['Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide']
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s stance on climate change has ignited a debate over a plan by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to reduce carbon emissions by putting a price on them.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau meets on Friday with the leaders of Canada’s provinces and territories to work out a national carbon pricing plan, Donald J. Trump will also be in the room, in a manner of speaking.

headline: At Christmas Cottage, Silver Bells and Sugar Plums Are Available Year Round
abstract: The attraction for the Midtown Manhattan store is deepest for shoppers at the onset of the holidays.
lead_paragraph: Even Manhattan’s hard edges soften at holiday time. Twinkle lights outglow fluorescents; sturdy woolen pompom hats replace flimsy knit beanies; marshmallow-speckled hot chocolate competes with black coffee.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Dec. 9, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “La La Land,” “Lost and Beautiful” and “Frank & Lola.”

About six black-capped chickadees had turned a bare gray birch into a sort of Christmas tree. As additional birds flitted in, they chattered and jockeyed for position. Clearly investigating my activities, within a few seconds a dozen birds were no more than a yard or two away. It struck me that I’ve received holiday cards that looked a lot like this.

headline: Grasping for Sanity in the Season of Fiscal Impairment

This steamer is about as effective as taking a sip of hot tea and then exhaling over a garment. Actually, exhaling would be more effective because then you might spot the garment and be forced to take it to a dry cleaner.

Mr. Merriweather, who begins most Sundays in his 15th-floor apartment in Harlem, is an accomplished baritone as well as the choirs’ musical director. He is also an assistant professor and director of choirs at Brooklyn College Conservatory of Music of the City University of New York.

headline: How to Play the Saw

headline: Keep It Moving
abstract: A recent study suggests that frequent activity, not just occasional bouts of exercise, is needed to counter the deleterious effects of too much sitting.
lead_paragraph: By now it is pretty well accepted both that physical inactivity is bad — recently linked to 6 percent of all cases of heart disease worldwide and 11 percent of all premature deaths in the United States — and that exercise is good, because it tends to increase life span and protect against heart disease. Yet few studies actually show that exercise reduces the unhealthful impacts of too much sitting. People who work out but also sit for long hours — active couch potatoes, you might say — may often share the same elevated risks for disease and early death as their less active peers.

headline: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers
abstract: Lauren Graham, the “Gilmore Girls” actress whose new memoir is No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list, says she has carefully calibrated just how revealing she wants to be.
lead_paragraph: I Will Follow: Let’s get the beta male confession out of the way — I used to watch “Gilmore Girls” with my wife, and I liked it. The characters’ rapport and repartee (rapportee?) were like throwbacks to the great “Thin Man” movies, and the series cultivated such a literary vibe during its original seven-year run that websites compiled vast reading lists from its allusions. All of which is to say: When I told my wife that Lauren Graham, who played Lorelai Gilmore, would be appearing at the 92nd Street Y in New York to promote her memoir, “Talking as Fast as I Can” (new at No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list), we were there in a trice. Picture William Shatner speaking to a crowd of “Star Trek” fans, only 98 percent female, and you’ll get the idea: lots of fellowship and laughter and screaming, with the center of attention gamely baffled and entertained by it all. “I love you, Lauren!” one woman shouted, and Graham, grinning widely at the sea of cellphone flash bulbs, deadpanned, “I love your adherence to ‘The use of photography is strictly prohibited.’ ”

headline: Rapid Evolution Saved This Fish From Pollution, Study Says
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Superfund', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Genetics and Heredity']
abstract: Distinct populations of Atlantic killifish developed adaptations that helped them survive in waters tainted by toxic leftovers of industrial manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: The State of New Jersey says you can’t eat the fish or shellfish from the Lower Passaic River and Newark Bay. That’s because they’re living in the Diamond Alkali Superfund Site, where toxic leftovers from the manufacture of chemicals like DDT and the infamous Agent Orange oozed into surrounding waterways to be taken up by the animals that inhabited them. It’s an evolutionary miracle some of these animals are even alive. No, seriously. A fish that adapted to survive in this water shows evolution at its finest, according to a study published Thursday in Science.

headline: Canada Today: Emissions Policy, Bird-Hunting and Meat Pie
keywords: ['Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', "Women's PGA Championship (Golf)", 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Hunting and Trapping']
abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with leaders to discuss carbon emissions, Canadian women’s golf got a shot in the arm and history was made on a telecast.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has not yet moved into the White House but his anticipated policies are already spurring debate over what actions, if any, Canada will need to take in response. That was the case on Friday when Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with the provincial and territorial leaders to work out a national approach to pricing on carbon emissions. Before the meeting, Mr. Trudeau set out a plan where the price — either through a fossil fuel tax or a cap-and-trade system of emission allowances — would reach 50 Canadian dollars, or about $38, a metric ton, or 2,205 pounds, over five years. He also warned that provinces that did not buy in would have the price imposed on them. During the presidential election campaign, Mr. Trump said that he would pull the United States out of the climate change commitments made by the Obama administration. Some Canadians, mostly Conservative politicians, say the economy will be in jeopardy if Canada goes ahead with carbon pricing in the absence of American action. But when I looked into the debate, I also found people who argued that moving now on carbon emissions could give Canada a competitive advantage.

Liberty Island is part of Statue of Liberty National Monument, created in increments by three American presidents (beginning with Calvin Coolidge in 1924) using their authority under the Antiquities Act. The National Park Service administers it, but it doesn’t belong to that agency. It was a demonstration of total mastery. This didn’t look so much like a job as a life: His work was his whole being.

At home in Brooklyn people know her as AnnMarie Sealey. Here in Osogbo they call her Ifaseye Orisabunmi Adeegbe.

Bush administration, we questioned the propriety of his father, President George H.W. Bush, working for Carlyle Group, an investment company that was, in effect, a major defense contractor. headline: At Tavo, Mexican With Stops Around the World

lead_paragraph: TAVO Julieta Ballesteros, who has made her name at a number of Mexican spots, including Crema, La Loteria and China Latina, has teamed up with Francisco Decrescenzo, a native of Monterrey, Mexico, and a fledgling restaurateur who developed his business plan while at the Stern School of Business at New York University. The menu’s Mexican approach is richly seasoned with global notions, the result of both partners’ travels. You will find Peking duck carnitas, chow fun noodles with corn and shrimp, and lamb chops in a chocolate-habanero sauce. Chorizo shumai, calamari in a blue cornmeal crust, and Cuban lasagna with adobo pulled pork and plantains are also available. The dining room is finished in copper, oak and white brick, and the restaurant gets its name, short for Gustavo, from one of Mr. Decrescenzo’s grandfathers. (Opens Friday): 615 Hudson Street (West 12th Street), 917-675-6454, tavonyc.com.

Holiday music is sonic propaganda, crackling down at us from ancient mall sound systems and pouring point-blank from the mouths of horrible neighbors. It erodes our humanity with its cheerful clichés. Resist the elves and the messiahs, the apple-cheeked grandmothers and the man-size golems of sentient snow; resist the melodies that jump and flip like windup toys. lead_paragraph: Call it cabinet selection as beauty pageant. As President-elect Donald J. Trump assembles his cabinet and prepares to govern, he is drawing on an underestimated asset: showmanship honed over years of television pageantry.

headline: Gathering Intelligence Is Dangerous. So Is Not Reading It.
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Donald Trump’s decision to receive briefings only once a week undermines the professionals who risk their lives to obtain critical information.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has so far chosen to receive only one intelligence briefing each week. His decision is an extraordinary departure from the practices of his predecessors who received a briefing every day, with the exception of Richard M. Nixon, who had extensive foreign policy experience before his 1968 election victory.

headline: Rauschenberg Foundation Chief Moving to Sotheby’s
abstract: The hiring of Christy MacLear, chief executive of the foundation, would fill “a void,” said the art adviser Allan Schwartzman.
lead_paragraph: Moving more aggressively onto the turf of commercial galleries, Sotheby’s is hiring Christy MacLear, the chief executive of the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation and before that the executive director of the Philip Johnson Glass House, to expand the auction house’s advisory services for living artists and for artists’ estates and foundations.

headline: For Republican Russia Hawks, a Dilemma Named Rex Tillerson
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Cold War Era', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans will have to reconcile a party catechism with their vote on Mr. Tillerson for secretary of state. He is close to Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans face a vexing dilemma with the impending presidency of Donald J. Trump: Will they maintain the tough line on Russia that has been central to their foreign policy for decades, or cede that ground to Democrats?

headline: ‘Sense8: A Christmas Special’ Is Coming to Netflix
abstract: This two-hour special from the Wachowskis and J. Michael Straczynski arrives on Friday, Dec. 23.
lead_paragraph: When last we saw the alluring, transcendentally attuned global citizens of Netflix’s “Sense8,” they were sailing into the North Atlantic on a fishing boat. But wherever they landed, trouble was sure to follow. And in “Sense8: A Christmas Special” (debuting Friday, Dec. 23) — a two-hour gift from the Wachowskis and J. Michael Straczynski, the masterminds of the series — it has. The stars are back in their own worlds, and in one another’s minds: Nomi (Jamie Clayton) hides in San Francisco; Riley (Tuppence Middleton) drugs Will (Brian J. Smith) in Amsterdam; life is upended for Lito (Miguel Ángel Silvestre) in Mexico; Sun (Doona Bae) languishes in a South Korean prison; Capheus (Toby Onwumere) tinkers with his bus in Nairobi; and Kala (Tina Desai) can’t keep Wolfgang (Max Riemelt), in Berlin, out of her marital bed in Mumbai. And the henchman Mr. Whispers (Terrence Mann) lurks. Meanwhile, there are birthdays and holidays to celebrate with raves, orgies and unconditional support — a joyful excuse to keep fans sated until Season 2 in May.

headline: ‘The Magic Flute,’ Trimmed Down, at the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: This 100-minute English-language version is tailored to families around the holidays.
lead_paragraph: We wouldn’t want to be the ones to trim an hour of Mozart’s sublime “The Magic Flute.” But several years ago, the Metropolitan Opera took up the scissors, creating a 100-minute English-language version tailored to families around the holidays.

headline: Mos Def Bids Goodbye to Music and Acting, at the Apollo
abstract: His farewell concert in his hometown, New York City, will take place Dec. 21 at the Apollo Theater.
lead_paragraph: Yasiin Bey, the rapper best known as Mos Def, announced earlier this year that he will retire from music and acting, and he’s following through. His farewell concerts in his hometown, New York City, will take place Wednesday, Dec. 21, and Thursday at the Apollo Theater before he moves on to the Kennedy Center in Washington. The Apollo is an appropriate spot, steeped in the African-American heritage and sense of community that Mos Def’s raps have constantly invoked, both with Talib Kweli in Black Star and in diverse projects on his own. Politics, history and a sense of cultural responsibility have always informed his work, usually with a touch light enough to avoid being didactic. With luck, he’ll continue getting his message across in other media. (212-531-5300, apollotheater.org)

headline: Your Best Eats of 2016
abstract: What was the best thing you ate this year?
lead_paragraph: Good morning. For all the good cheer and pine-scented sidewalks, there is something ghostly and wistful about these December days, as we cast our eyes back toward the year that was. Pete Wells wrote about his top 10 restaurants of the year, and about the best dishes he ate for the Food section we blue-bagged and delivered to doors, porches and bushes this morning. (For those dining on the cheap in New York City, Ligaya Mishan offered her own list of bests.)

headline: A Trump Cabinet Pick and the Ties That Bind
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The Times was slow to tell readers that three big names rolled out by the president-elect to talk up Rex Tillerson had all worked for Exxon Mobil.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday began as most days do when Donald Trump is announcing a cabinet pick. At precisely 6:43 a.m. the president elect sent out a tweet announcing that he would nominate Rex Tillerson, C.E.O. of Exxon Mobil, to be the next secretary of state.

headline: Inquisitive Child Inspires Her Tutor to Start a New Path
abstract: At an internship last year, a girl Naivon Lake Jr. was tutoring asked why he wasn’t in college. Good question, Naivon thought.
lead_paragraph: An innocent question posed by a young girl led Naivon Lake Jr. to chart out a new course in his life.

headline: Abortion Is Found to Have Little Effect on Women’s Mental Health
abstract: A study, published in JAMA Psychiatry, undermines the claim that women seeking abortions might develop emotional and psychological trauma.
lead_paragraph: It’s an idea that has long been used as an argument against abortion — that terminating a pregnancy causes women to experience emotional and psychological trauma.

headline: The Works of Lucinda Childs, Online and Absorbing
abstract: “A Steady Pulse,” a digital archive published last year by the Pew Center, offers a close look at eight works created between 1963 and 1978.
lead_paragraph: The Lucinda Childs Dance Company recently wrapped up a two-week season at the Joyce Theater, surveying several decades of its founder’s mesmerizing minimalism. If you missed it — or even if you didn’t — the next best thing is “A Steady Pulse,” an absorbing digital archive published last year by the Pew Center for Arts and Heritage. Late December’s dance lull (various versions of “The Nutcracker” notwithstanding) is the perfect time to dive into this collection, which offers a close look at eight works created by Ms. Childs between 1963 and 1978.

headline: Tomás Saraceno at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
abstract: “Tomás Saraceno: Stillness in Motion — Cloud Cities” is a complex of cords and reflective panels built to evoke a 10,000-node airborne habitation.
lead_paragraph: In “The Empire Strikes Back,” we learned that a city in the clouds was not such a great idea. “I’ve had supply problems of every kind — I’ve had labor difficulties,” grouses Lando Calrissian, the dashing administrator of the movie’s gravity-defying metropolis.

headline: Christie’s Chief Executive to Step Down and Hand Reins to Guillaume Cerutti
abstract: The executive, Patricia Barbizet, will be vice chairwoman. Mr. Cerutti is taking over at a time when auction houses are struggling to fill sales with inventory.
lead_paragraph: In yet another jolt to the auction world, coming just one week after Christie’s top business-getter, Brett Gorvy, announced his departure, the house announced that its chief executive, Patricia Barbizet, was also stepping down, as of Jan. 1, after two years at the helm.

headline: Veterans Help Make San Diego a Hub for Start-Ups
abstract: The concentration of military bases, along with business programs for former military personnel, has fueled a growth in entrepreneurship.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — For decades, politicians lobbied to bring military bases to their districts for one reason: jobs. A base is akin to a corporate headquarters, bringing with it jobs in related businesses.

headline: ‘Christmas Is a Drag’ Dresses Up for the Holidays
abstract: Several contestants from “RuPaul’s Drag Race” have been featured already, and entertainers including Jackie Beat will perform in this monthlong series.
lead_paragraph: How can you not feel holiday spirit when standing up at the Laurie Beechman Theater, swaying your arms and singing “Let There Be Peace on Earth” with the drag queen Ginger Minj? Such was my enviable lot recently, and while that show is over, the monthlong “Christmas Is a Drag” series at the Beechman continues this week with some of the most offbeat holiday entertainment you’ll find.

headline: The Farming Life in an Older Italy, at Film Forum
abstract: “The Tree of the Wooden Clogs,” Ermanno Olmi’s Palme d’Or-winning film of Italian peasant families in the late 19th century, is showing.
lead_paragraph: “The Tree of Wooden Clogs,” Ermanno Olmi’s farsighted view of Italian farm life in the late 19th century, immerses you in what feels like an unchanging preindustrial world. The beautiful three-hour film, which won the Palme d’Or at Cannes in 1978, follows the lives of four peasant families laboring on the estate of an absentee landlord in the province of Bergamo. The actors, all residents of the area, speak in their native dialect.

headline: Trump Firm Quits Brazil Hotel Project That Was Named in Criminal Inquiry
abstract: The hotel and another Trump venture in the city had been named in a federal investigation over investments by public pension fund managers in commercial projects.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Trump Organization says it is pulling out of a troubled hotel project in Rio de Janeiro, just weeks after a federal prosecutor opened a criminal investigation that included the hotel and another Trump venture in the city.

headline: Our Favorite Travel Photography of 2016
abstract: A collection of some of our favorite photography from this year, including a road trip through Namibia and Ireland’s gorgeous lighthouses.
lead_paragraph: A collection of some of our favorite photography from this year, including a road trip through Namibia and Ireland’s gorgeous lighthouses.

headline: Biggest Tech Failures and Successes of 2016
keywords: ['Batteries', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Wireless Communications', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Computer Security', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: From exploding smartphones and hoverboards to fake news on social media, many tech hardware, software and web products suffered embarrassing setbacks. But it was not all bleak.
lead_paragraph: If you love technology, it may be time for a group hug: This year has been rough for consumer technology.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte on Killing Criminal Suspects: ‘I Used to Do It Personally’
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs']
abstract: “I was really looking for a confrontation, so I could kill,” President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines told business leaders at a meeting in Manila.
lead_paragraph: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines, overseer of a contentious and bloody crackdown on drug dealers and users, boasted on Monday about having personally killed criminal suspects when he was mayor of Davao City.

headline: Four Not-to-Miss Photography Shows
abstract: These exhibitions celebrate unusual subjects, from simple household objects to newly arrived immigrants at Ellis Island.
lead_paragraph: From kitchen sinks to chancellors and immigrants to burlesque queens, these four photography shows light up the season. Three are by contemporaries working in color, and one by a gifted amateur recording America’s diversity in the early 20th century.

headline: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 15
abstract: Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers and Falcons running back Devonta Freeman have favorable matchups this week.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: National Film Registry Adds ‘The Lion King’ and ‘Thelma and Louise’
abstract: The Library of Congress announced its latest additions on Wednesday, which also include “The Breakfast Club,” “The Birds,” “East of Eden” and “Lost Horizon.”
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in the Library of Congress the Breakfast Club will always be meeting for a Saturday morning’s detention, a young lion named Simba will perpetually have no worries for the rest of his days and Thelma and Louise will be forever holding hands as they speed toward the Grand Canyon. The motion pictures that made these characters memorable are among the 25 that have been selected for preservation in the library’s National Film Registry.

headline: SAG Nominees Include Viggo Mortensen and Other Surprises
abstract: Manchester by the Sea” lands the most nominations, with “Fences” and “Moonlight” close behind.
lead_paragraph: The Screen Actors Guild entered the awards season fray with its nominations on Wednesday, which included a few surprises:

headline: 2016 in Review: The Year’s Best Apps
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Computer and Video Games', 'News and News Media', 'Podcasts', 'Cameras', 'Beer']
abstract: A news curator based on what friends are reading, an easy-to-access universe of NPR audio, and an upgraded beer-tracking app are among our top picks.
lead_paragraph: MORE than four million software programs are available in the Apple and Google app stores, including games, productivity tools and weather apps.

headline: Pain Relievers Tied to Hearing Loss
abstract: Regular use of drugs like Advil or Tylenol for six years or longer may slightly increase the risk for hearing loss.
lead_paragraph: Long term use of pain relievers may increase the risk for hearing loss, according to new findings.

headline: Leggings in a Kaleidoscope of Patterns, for Almost Every Occasion
abstract: Terez is known for its playful leggings, festooned with photo-real prints of cookies, dogs and emoji, the company’s best seller.
lead_paragraph: In pursuit of the perfect legging print, Zara Tisch has baked and photographed chocolate chip cookies, used a tweezer to set crystals in a skull shape, and spent a year arranging and rearranging cassette tapes to figure out the most leg-lengthening configuration.

headline: A New Japanese Restaurant With an Artist’s Sensibility
abstract: Maiko Kyogoku was inspired by Takashi Murakami, her former employer, in creating Bessou.
lead_paragraph: In Japanese, the word “bessou” refers to a second house that’s used for vacations or quick getaways — a home away from home. In New York’s NoHo neighborhood, it’s the name of a new restaurant from Maiko Kyogoku, a Japanese-American restaurateur who worked with the contemporary artist Takashi Murakami before opening Bessou.

headline: Times Critics’ Top Books of 2016
abstract: The Times’s critics give their choices of the best fiction and nonfiction works of the year.
lead_paragraph: The Italian writer Italo Calvino defined a classic as “a book that’s never finished saying what it has to say.” This year, The Times’s daily critics reviewed nearly 250 titles. What follows are their lists of the fiction and nonfiction books that most moved, excited and enlightened them in 2016 — books that, in their own ways, are perhaps not finished saying what they have to say.

headline: To Protect Civilians, Pentagon Tightens Rules on Combat
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The changes are the second time this year that the Defense Department has modified its Law of War Manual in response to criticism that portions were inaccurate or dangerous.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon has revised a 2015 manual for waging combat while obeying the international laws of war, tightening rules for when it is lawful to fire on a military target even though civilians — from human shields to workers at weapons factories — are nearby.

headline: Israel’s Parliament Draws a Line on Short Hemlines
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Dresses']
abstract: Dozens of female employees arrived at the Knesset in above-the-knee outfits to protest what they said was a sudden shift in enforcing a longstanding dress code.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — How short is a short skirt and who gets to decide?

headline: The Quest for Your Dream Streamer
keywords: ['Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mobile Applications', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: The wide array of available video-streaming devices can be overwhelming, but a bit of research will help you figure out what features you really need.
lead_paragraph: Q. There seems to be quite a range of prices on streaming video set-top boxes and sticks. What more do you really get with the more expensive ones priced at $150 or more, compared with the plug-in sticks that cost $30 to $40?

headline: Daily Report: When Cars and Tech Repeatedly Collide
abstract: The government proposed rules requiring new cars and small trucks to transmit speed, location and direction data, and Alphabet is spinning off its self-driving project.
lead_paragraph: Technology is sweeping through cars, and cars are sweeping through the tech industry. Both of those forces were abundantly on display this week.

headline: BBC and ITV to Offer Streaming Service of British Shows in U.S.
abstract: The service will be available by March and will offer a combination of new shows as well as a collection of recently aired programs and other offerings from the broadcasters’ back catalogs.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated that you cannot watch the latest British dramas or soap operas on television?

headline: Jewelry That Draws From a Japanese Technique — and Constructivist Sculpture
abstract: Yolande Batteau of Callidus Guild and Randi Mates of Aesa launch their first official collaboration: a line of precious metal and wood earrings and pendants.
lead_paragraph: Coming from different, and multiple, milieus, the close friends Yolande Batteau and Randi Mates meet in the middle — that is, 82nd Street and Fifth Avenue. “We have a mutual devotion to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, particularly the study rooms,” says Batteau, a painter and co-founder of the noted interiors studio Callidus Guild, of Mates (herself a classical goldsmith and Aesa jewelry founder). “The level of our mutuality is such that we can go to a museum together, separate to wander for an hour and then come together only to find we have taken photos of the same exact pieces,” Mates adds. “It’s a rare and thrilling experience to find another person who is as wholly enamored by history, the minutiae of objects and the deep physicality of materials as I am.”

headline: One Small Step for NASA, One Giant Leap for GIFs
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: The space agency has entered a partnership with Giphy to share clips of science in action.
lead_paragraph: Last week, NASA announced that it would open an official account at Giphy, a GIF database and social media platform, bringing the space agency up to speed with the way young people communicate in the internet age.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte, Aleppo, Donald Trump: Your Morning Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Go to the Wrong Hospital and You’re 3 Times More Likely to Die
abstract: Patients at the worst institutions were three times more likely to die and 13 times more likely to have medical complications than at one of the best, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: Not all hospitals are created equal, and the differences in quality can be a matter of life or death.

headline: GoFundMe Says It Has Helped Campaigns Raise $3 Billion
abstract: The crowdfunding site has become synonymous with online giving to help in disasters and smaller crises. Some fear it could hurt traditional charities.
lead_paragraph: Three days after a 28-year-old man took an AR-15 rifle into a Washington pizzeria to investigate false reports of a child trafficking ring, an online fund-raising effort for the business was already underway.

headline: How the Fed’s Interest Rate Increase Can Affect You
abstract: The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. Economists talk about the impact on markets, but what about everyday consumers?
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday for just the second time since the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Fed Raises Key Interest Rate, Citing Strengthening Economy
abstract: The increase was only the second since the financial crisis, and the central bank gave little indication that Donald J. Trump’s election altered its outlook.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate Wednesday for just the second time since the financial crisis of 2008, saying the American economy is expanding at a healthy pace and setting itself up as a counterweight to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s push for considerably faster growth.

headline: Baftas So White, but They’re Working on It
abstract: The British Academy of Film and Television Arts has set new requirements to help foster diversity in the British film industry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It isn’t just the Oscars that are so white; and it isn’t just the Oscars that are trying to fix it.

headline: Italian Parliament Approves New Government, for Now
abstract: Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni won the support of both houses this week, but political debate has danced around one question: How long will it last?
lead_paragraph: ROME — A week after Matteo Renzi resigned as prime minister of Italy, the former Foreign Minister Paolo Gentiloni took his place, winning the support of both chambers of Parliament in back-to-back confidence votes on Tuesday and Wednesday.

headline: Review: ‘The Bodyguard’ Is Shadowed by a Stalker, and a Superstar
abstract: This stage adaptation of the 1992 Whitney Houston film, at Paper Mill Playhouse, features lots of Houston hits but characters of minimal dimensions.
lead_paragraph: MILLBURN, N.J. — The stage version of “The Bodyguard” isn’t the worst musical made from the boiled bones of a movie. In fact, I’m not sure it would make the top five (or do I mean bottom five?), although aside from a couple of shudder-worthy disasters, memory has expunged the details of many such shows.

headline: Spared by Gunman in Charleston, Churchgoer Describes Night of Terror
abstract: The defense rested without calling any witnesses in the trial of Dylann Roof, who is accused of killing nine people in June 2015.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Polly Sheppard, a 72-year-old retired nurse and longtime stalwart of Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, dived under a table as the gunfire began and did the only thing she could think to do: She prayed aloud. She could see the bullet casings skittering across the floor of the fellowship hall and the young man’s boots approaching. Dylann S. Roof told her to “shut up,” then asked menacingly if he had shot her yet.

headline: Swimming With the Mysterious Sardine Disco Balls of the Philippines
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Swimming', 'Diving and Divers']
abstract: Around a handful of beaches on the island of Cebu, divers can swim with sparkling aggregations of fish that collect in “bait balls.”
lead_paragraph: Thousands to millions of sardines emerge from a coral wall in cobalt waters just a few yards from the shores of Cebu Island in the Philippines. They move in a single undulating cloud of silver that twists, turns, shrinks, expands and wraps itself around any object that gets in its way. At times, it becomes a thundercloud, blocking out the sun or clapping violently as it suddenly flips its formation to evade a predator.

headline: Thursday’s N.F.L. Matchup: Los Angeles Rams (4-9) at Seattle Seahawks (8-4-1)
abstract: The Seahawks are seeking to end an inexplicable streak of three straight losses to the Rams, who fired Coach Jeff Fisher on Monday.

abstract: Flummoxed by the old-fashioned pastime of entertaining at home, our reporter tries out online services designed to bring together strangers.

About an hour later, he took broader questions, including several on the latest in a string of high-level departures from health and human services departments.

headline: Tell Investors of Climate Risks, Energy Sector Is Urged

lead_paragraph: A coalition of the world’s most powerful bankers, regulators and even executives at some heavy polluters have a message for oil and gas companies: Be more forthcoming about the risks posed by climate change.

headline: In Jazz, Listen to the Timeless Elders
keywords: ['Jazz', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Country Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Age, Chronological', 'Music', 'Elderly']
abstract: The music is an art of living traditions and accumulated wisdom, so it’s only natural that its veterans remain central to the conversation.
lead_paragraph: Among the things often said of Ron Carter — that he’s one of the most influential and widely recorded bassists in history, a distinguished professor of music, a multiple Grammy winner and a National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Master — there’s one that may not be said often enough. The man knows how to wear a suit.

headline: Notes on the Macroeconomic Situation
abstract: No boom, bigger trade deficits.
lead_paragraph: So the Fed has raised rates. It was, I’d argue, a mistake, although not as severe a mistake as it would have been a year ago. Anyway, it seems like a good time to review where I think the economy stands, and what it means for monetary and fiscal policy.

headline: ‘I’m Here to Help,’ Trump Tells Tech Executives at Meeting
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The president-elect met with Jeff Bezos of Amazon and Timothy D. Cook of Apple, among other tech leaders, in a surprisingly genial gathering.
lead_paragraph: The meeting between President-elect Donald J. Trump and the nation’s tech elite was hyped as something out of “The Apprentice”: The new boss tells his minions to shape up. It turned out to be a charm offensive, a kind of “Dancing With the Silicon Valley Stars.”

headline: Getting a Drone as a Gift? Check Your Insurance
abstract: Demand for drones has surged, in part because of their lower cost, but consumers should know that some companies may exclude related accidents from their policies.
lead_paragraph: MANY people will receive drones as gifts this holiday season. But before heading to the nearest field to fly the devices, recipients may want to check their insurance coverage.

headline: For Josh Groban, a Boot Camp for Broadway
abstract: To prepare for his role in “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812,” he tackled the accordion — and, reluctantly, learned to dance.
lead_paragraph: Josh Groban has sold more than 30 million records, making him a household name all over the world. But when he began talking to the producers and creators behind the Broadway-bound musical “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812,” it was clear he’d need to learn a few things.

headline: Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival Unveils 2017 Season
abstract: The festival’s 85th season includes a tap program organized by Michelle Dorrance and a site-specific work by the troupe Pilobolus.
lead_paragraph: A tap program organized by Michelle Dorrance, a site-specific work by the troupe Pilobolus and rare visits from Cuban and Canadian companies are in store for the 85th season of Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival.

headline: Memorable Theater of 2016: Twining Twins, Bathroom Sex and Cod Kisses
abstract: Our writers, editors and critics single out indelible scenes from the past year onstage.
lead_paragraph: “Hamilton” continued its remarkable reign. Even the vice president-elect checked it out — though maybe he wishes he hadn’t. We end the year still thinking about the searing performances, challenging stagecraft and oddball experiments that make theater anything but a safe space. Here New York Times writers, editors and critics single out moments to remember.

abstract: Shelling resumed Wednesday in rebel-held neighborhoods of Aleppo, Syria, halting a planned the evacuation of thousands of civilians. A ceasefire reached the night before, involving Russia and Turkey, seemed to have fallen through.

abstract: President-elect Trump has said the U.S. is too accommodating to China and that the One China policy could be negotiable.

headline: On ‘Patriots Day’: ‘Love Will Defeat Evil’

headline: 36 Hours in Nairobi, Kenya
abstract: Intense traffic, a strong multicultural vibe, big global businesses — and yet you can still feed giraffes and elephants within the city limits.
lead_paragraph: Nairobi, the capital of Kenya, calls itself the City in the Sun, and a visit can be as pleasant as that sounds. Most outsiders drop in for two reasons: business and animals. A short flight from spectacular wildlife parks such as the Maasai Mara, Nairobi has also become a magnet for some of the world’s biggest corporations trying to gain a foothold in Africa. The city is surprisingly beautiful with flowering trees and the perfect climate: 70s and 80s, sunny, low humidity — almost every day. It’s a palpably multicultural place, encapsulating what is happening in Africa better than any other city on the continent. Picture new construction, a lot of people, intense traffic, and more and more Western businesses. Yet you can still feed giraffes and baby elephants from within the city limits and see Maasai warriors ordering lattes in red-checkered blankets.

Religious groups are also allowed to give faith-based instruction in public schools: It’s not uncommon for a small-town pastor, priest or lay person to have a spot on the local high school faculty.

headline: Is It Possible to Make a Less Allergenic Peanut?

lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1987, Wesley Burks, a pediatric allergist in Little Rock, decided to enroll in a graduate-level biochemistry course at the University of Arkansas. Twice a week, instead of driving to his laboratory at the Arkansas Children’s Hospital, he headed to the medical-school campus about a mile away. There, he joined some 20 students learning to pipette liquid extracts into gels and stain them with pigments to figure out which protein molecules they contained. Burks had only recently completed his medical fellowship, where he studied why some children have allergic reactions to milk and eggs. Now he was throwing himself into biochemistry so he could be the first to figure out what it was about peanuts that made people so allergic. “It’s easy to say you want to do something that’ll change kids’ lives,” Burks says. “But you have to focus on an area to really get it done.”

headline: Review: Beneath the Bombast, ‘Fences’ Has an Aching Poetry

He enters the screen on a tide of verbiage, jawing with his friend Bono (Stephen McKinley Henderson) and bantering with his wife, Rose (Viola Davis). The audience quickly grasps what Rose and Bono have known for years. Troy is by turns funny, provocative, inspiring and hurtful, but one thing he will never be as long as he draws breath is silent.

headline: To Protect the Land, Jared Sternberg Turned to Tourism

lead_paragraph: The New Orleans resident Jared Sternberg, 30, started Gondwana Ecotours in 2013, the same year he graduated from Tulane University Law School in that city. He studied environmental and human rights with the idea of helping indigenous and underserved populations preserve land and resources, but after completing service work in locations including Ghana, Ecuador, Alaska and Nicaragua, Mr. Sternberg became convinced that tourism could achieve the same goals. This year, Gondwana offered trips to six destinations on three continents. (The name Gondwana refers to an ancient landmass.)

A stuffed monkey lounges on a branch, a homage to Bua Noi (Little Lotus), a gorilla who has spent her life in the rooftop zoo of the Pata department store in Bangkok.

headline: What E.U. Leaders Are Wrestling With at the End of a Tough Year
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Referendums', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Officials tiptoed through a geopolitical minefield as they gathered in Brussels for their end-of-year summit meeting. Here’s a guide to the thorniest issues.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union has had a rough year, buffeted by terrorism, “Brexit,” far-right populism and lethargic growth, and leaders of its member states were tiptoeing through a geopolitical minefield on Thursday during their end-of-year summit meeting in Brussels. The migration crisis has abated, but only slightly, and collective decision-making is harder than ever. Referendums, like Britain’s June 23 vote to leave the European Union and Italy’s Dec. 4 decision to reject constitutional changes, have made life harder for democratically elected leaders. The war in Syria, aggression and meddling by Russia and the election of Donald J. Trump as the United States president have added to the complexity.

Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Lois Weber, Eloquent Filmmaker of the Silent Screen
abstract: The Anthology Film Archives is giving viewers a chance to discover this long-forgotten director with a beautiful restoration of her 1916 film “The Dumb Girl of Portici.”
lead_paragraph: Once upon a Hollywood time, one of filmdom’s biggest directors was Lois Weber. Woodrow Wilson was president, and women couldn’t have voted for him even if they had wanted to, but inside the movie industry, women thrived, and Weber thrived above all others. An auteur before that word entered the cinematic lexicon, she wrote, directed and edited films and was admired for her sensitive work with actors, her on-set meticulousness and her stories about women. Her name was invoked alongside the likes of D. W. Griffith, yet, like most female directors of that era, she faded into obscurity.

headline: Man, 73, Shot Dead by Officer Had a Crucifix, Not a Gun, Police Say

A deal will require some unusual ingredients.

headline: Like Drinking Cocktails at Home, in L.A.

lead_paragraph: Reza Fahim designed Tenants of the Trees, a nightclub in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles, for the new generation of Hollywood stars that relishes privacy: It’s surrounded by 14-foot high concrete walls. Within the cramped, labyrinthine corridors of Tenants, on the smallest dance floor in Los Angeles, Frank Ocean swayed incognito on the night his long-anticipated second album, “Blonde,” dropped last August. And on a recent Thursday night, the burgeoning London rockers the Big Moon claimed a cabaret stage to play a secret concert to close their first North American tour; unbeknown to them, the band served as an opening act for an impromptu two-hour set by Dave Chappelle.

headline: Can I Stay at a Hotel When Visiting My Crowded Family Home?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Gifts', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: Also: When you realize you didn’t get an invitation to a holiday party you’ve gone to for years; the complexities of gift giving, and more.
lead_paragraph: I am 55 and the oldest of four siblings. We all congregate at our parents’ home (with spouses and kids) over the holidays. Their place has many bedrooms but only two baths. The commotion is fun during the day, but at night, the house is overcrowded and noisy. For a few years, I have gotten a hotel room three blocks away. I only use it for sleeping and showering. But sleeping there, instead of on the couch, causes resentment in the family, especially from my mother. How can I explain that I don’t mean offense?

abstract: Ms. Pensato’s new Brooklyn studio is already filled with her collection of toys and figurines, but she says she wants the place to be “a lot dirtier.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s getting there,” the painter Joyce Pensato said. Hands on her hips, she was scrutinizing the cluttered, paint-splattered length of a studio in Bushwick, Brooklyn, that she moved into about a year ago, after the building that housed her previous studio, a spiritual sanctuary for more than 30 years, was sold. “I need to get this a lot dirtier, a lot more stuffed. lead_paragraph: Craig Sager, an exuberant sideline reporter for National Basketball Association television broadcasts who was as well known for his outlandishly garish outfits as for the questions he asked coaches and players, died on Thursday in Atlanta. He was 65.
